stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain the oxygen cascade?

prompts.text: What is the oxygen cascade and what are the values at each step?
expectedKeyFacts: Describes progressive fall in partial pressure of oxygen from atmosphere to mitochondria
Atmospheric PO₂: 21 kPa (160 mmHg) at sea level
Humidified inspired gas: 20 kPa (150 mmHg)
Alveolar PO₂: 13-14 kPa (100 mmHg)
Arterial PO₂: 12-13 kPa (90-100 mmHg)
Mixed venous PO₂: 5.3 kPa (40 mmHg)
Mitochondrial PO₂: <1 kPa

prompts.text: Why does the partial pressure of oxygen fall at each step?
expectedKeyFacts: Humidification: Water vapour pressure 6.3 kPa dilutes inspired oxygen
Alveolar gas equation: PAO₂ = PiO₂ - (PACO₂/R) where R = respiratory quotient ~0.8
Alveolar-arterial gradient: V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion limitation
Normal A-a gradient <2 kPa, increases with age
Tissue extraction: oxygen diffuses down concentration gradient to mitochondria
Venous PO₂ reflects tissue extraction and oxygen consumption

prompts.text: How would you calculate the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen for a patient breathing 40% oxygen at sea level?
expectedKeyFacts: Alveolar gas equation: PAO₂ = PiO₂ - (PACO₂/R)
FiO₂ = 0.4, atmospheric pressure = 101 kPa
PiO₂ = FiO₂ × (Patm - PH₂O) = 0.4 × (101 - 6.3) = 38 kPa
Assume PACO₂ = 5.3 kPa, R = 0.8
Therefore PAO₂ ~31 kPa on 40% oxygen

prompts.text: A patient has a PaO₂ of 8 kPa on room air. How would you assess the severity and determine the cause?
expectedKeyFacts: Calculate A-a gradient: PAO₂ - PaO₂
If normal PAO₂ ~13 kPa, A-a gradient = 13 - 8 = 5 kPa (raised)
Normal gradient: hypoventilation (increased PACO₂ lowers PAO₂)
Raised gradient: V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion defect
Check PACO₂: if low (hyperventilating), likely V/Q or shunt
Response to oxygen: shunt does not improve with high FiO₂
Calculate P/F ratio: PaO₂/FiO₂ (normal >40 kPa or >300 mmHg)
Perform shunt calculation if available

prompts.text: Why is the A-a gradient more useful than PaO₂ alone in assessing gas exchange?
expectedKeyFacts: PaO₂ depends on both alveolar PO₂ and gas exchange efficiency
Hypoventilation lowers PAO₂ and PaO₂ equally — normal gradient
Intrinsic lung disease increases A-a gradient
A-a gradient isolates gas exchange defect from ventilatory failure
Age-related increase in gradient — formula: A-a = (Age/4) + 4 in kPa
Allows assessment of lung pathology independent of ventilation
P/F ratio also useful but A-a gradient more physiologically precise

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the alveolar gas equation — what does it describe and what are the key components?
keyFacts: Oxygen cascade: progressive fall in PO₂ from atmosphere to mitochondria
Atmospheric 21 kPa → Inspired 20 kPa → Alveolar 13 kPa → Arterial 12 kPa → Venous 5.3 kPa
A-a gradient normally <2 kPa, increases with age
Causes of increased A-a gradient: V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion defect
Shunt: persistent hypoxaemia despite high FiO₂

scoringGuidance.pass: Describes oxygen cascade with approximate values, explains alveolar gas equation, can calculate PAO₂, understands A-a gradient and its causes, can differentiate hypoventilation from V/Q mismatch; stronger candidates explain age-related changes and shunt calculation
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows oxygen levels fall from air to tissues but values unclear, mentions alveolar gas equation but cannot apply it, vague on A-a gradient interpretation
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe oxygen cascade, does not know alveolar gas equation, unaware of A-a gradient concept or its clinical significance
